columns.text: In this problem, we will assess the possible factors that can maintain the profit margin in the market.

As discussed in the chapter, as more firms enter a market, the profit margin decreases for all until it eventually becomes saturated that the profit margin is equal to zero. 

In the case of the Cayenne, since not a lot of firms are in the luxury SUV market, then the profit margin is still very high. The lower the number of firms in a market, the higher the profitability.

Additionally, the Porsche brand is always embedded into the Cayenne which gives it the boost over other SUVs due to the prestige of the brand. This ensures that the performance of the Cayenne in terms of the business will always be better than the other competitors, barring possible blemishes to the company's reputation.

This means that as long as there are few firms in the market, the profit margin will be high. If more firms enter the market, the profit margin will be lower but due to the luxury of the brand, it will still be higher than most competitors in the same market of luxury SUVs.
For this question, we would like an opinion regarding Porscheâ€™s substantial margins that could still exist in the market.

Porsche might well acknowledge that perhaps the overly inflated revenues would wither away as even more brands entered the demand and contestability increased. The latter primary brief exemplar of Porsche's SUV course of action thus raises a few other huge issues. 

If a corporation is doing something innovative, such as the iPhone, those certain manufacturers will rush to enter that lucrative market. Therefore, to remain afloat, businesses should constantly innovate and try to eliminate expenditures.
